episode.title: Franks v. Bowman Transportation Company, Inc.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: We will hear arguments next in Franks and Lee against Bowman Transportation Company.
Mr. Baller you may proceed whenever you are ready.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the court.

This Court granted Certiorari to determine whether the District Courts have the power to restore victims of hiring discrimination based on race to the present seniority positions which they would have occupied but for the discriminatory practices.
The issue is presented both under Title VII of Civil Rights Act of 1964 and other 42 U.S. Code Section 1981.

The Court Of Appeals for the Fifth Circuit held and awarded retroactive seniority beyond the power of the District Courts because in its view, such an award would violate Section 703 (h) of Title VII.
That Section provides that an employer may lawfully use a bona fide seniority or merit system, provided that it is not the result of an intention to discriminate.
The Court of Appeals did not specifically address the question under Section 1981.
The legal issues presented in this case arises in circumstances of unvarnished racial discrimination in employment.

The District Court found that respondent Bowman Transportation had pursued a policy of excluding black employees and applicants from all but a few of the lowest paying most menial jobs in the company.
The enactment of Title VII had stimulated no change in Bowman’s policies.
The company continued to discriminate in virtually every aspect of its operations for years after Title VII became effective.
And indeed was still engaged in most of its discriminatory practices at the time of trial in March 1972.
The District Court’s findings as to Bowman’s discriminatory practices read like a virtual catalog of unlawful employment practices under Title VII.

Maintenance of segregated jobs and segregated departments, a job seniority system, no transfer rules, illegal, unvalidated testing, racial assignment and steering of new employees, word of mouth recruitment and retaliation against those few black employees who tried to better themselves despite this system.
The record presents no mitigating circumstances.
Before this court specifically, are claims arising from Bowman’s rejection of the applications of qualified black truck driver applicants.
This policy of exclusion remained absolute until the eve of filing of petitioner’s suit.
Until September 1970, Bowman had never hired a single black over the road driver to fill its approximately 500 road driver jobs.
In September 1970, Bowman began to hire a few black truck drivers at one of its terminals but continued to resist hiring black truck drivers at its other terminals.
At one of its major Truck Driver terminals in Charlotte, the first black truck was hired only a month before trial.
During the period 1969 to 1971 which is the focus of this claim, hundreds of black truck driver applicants applied to Bowman.
Many of these applicants were fully qualified under Bowman’s usual standards for hiring.
During the same time Bowman did hire in excess of 200 white truck drivers each year.
Many of this white truck drivers lacked adequate or minimum qualifications.
And up to 150 of these whites were hired as trainees even though they lacked the minimum truck driving experience supposedly required.
Bowman hired these white trainees upon the personal recommendation of members of its all white or nearly all white road driver work force.
When these unqualified whites were hired along with many other whites who were no better qualified than dozens of unsuccessful black applicants.
They began to accumulate employment date seniority.
At trial the District Court certified this case as a class action and designated several sub-classes.
One of them, denominated class three and represented by petitioner Lee consists of rejected black road driver applicants.
Over 200 individuals were identified.
Those individuals were given notice and were invited to reapply for hiring by Bowman with priority consideration but without retroactive seniority.
There after, a few class three members reapplied and were hired began to drive trucks for Bowman.
However, they took as their employment seniority date, the date of their actual hiring.

Months or even years after they had initially filed their applications and months or even years later than the employment seniority date of many whites who had initially applied at the same time they did.
Under the ruling of the Fifth Circuit, these blacks, in their seniority standing will never catch up with the whites who were hired ahead of them.
Today or tomorrow, when one of these black employees competes with a contemporary white applicant, he will loose out in bidding and he will have less security from lay-off.
Moreover, he will have lesser fringe benefits than he can—

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When the seniority is granted, that is at who's expense in a sense, if the seniority is retroactively granted, what happens to the man who -- how’s the seniority now, this is not something that can be divided, is it?
It has to be taken away from one person in order to give it to another.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: We do not seek to take seniority from any white driver.
We simply insist that he compete using his full seniority with blacks using their full seniority.
The competition within be governed among qualified employees by the full measure of seniority for all of them.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But can it make a difference (Inaudible)?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: It would make a difference in competitive position, Mr. Justice Brennan.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: It would mean perhaps of that a black driver would retain a job when a white driver would have to be laid off.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is theoretically correct.
In this case it is quite clear.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, is that practically correct? Or do you have a—

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: As a practical matter in this case Mr. Justice Brennan we have a high turn over situation.
The record shows that about half the road drivers turn over each year and it --

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: This decision will not be for this case alone?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: I am aware of that.
As a practical matter the grant of retroactive seniority would subject whites to increase competition for all the things that seniority gives access to including security from lay off.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It suggests that somewhere in your brief, I got the impression that you at least (Inaudible) that they took these jobs with a sort of a lien on them even though they might be innocent of any participation in the failure on the conduct on which this action is based.
Is that the theory that they do take it to at some sort of a lien or cloud on the title seniority.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: The question is not the quality of behavior of the whites who were hired, it is the quality of behavior of the company in rejecting blacks and the remedy would—

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But if you take something away from the driver hired earlier, you are depriving him of something that he thought that he had, are you not?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice I would reiterate our position that we do not seek to take any seniority away from whites, they will have to compete with blacks also enable to utilize their seniority but we feel that is the central thrust of the law.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Going to the specific practical problems Mr. Justice Brennan alluded to on a lay off and we must deal with the generality and not the idiosyncrasies of this company.
On a lay-off, someone is going to be laid off, if retroactive seniority is accorded to the class that you represent, is that not so?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: If a lay-off comes and it cuts deep enough to involve the seniority dates we are talking about, that would be correct.
Yes, your Honor.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: How would we justify taking away in affect, taking away from Peter to pay Paul?
Both of them are innocent of any wrong doing.
Each of them is innocent to any wrong doing.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice the lay-off issue, I would suggest is in fact not a single issue but a series of issues which may arise in different situations, none of which of course are presented in this case.
We submit that there will be, it is lurking in this case.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: It is lurking in this case, is it not?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: We submit that there will be cases in which as a result of restitution of seniority rights to black employees followed by lay-offs, there may indeed the white employees unable under those circumstances to all their jobs.
We think that is what Congress had in mind when it opened up all jobs to fair competition between blacks and whites alike.
We are not here suggesting, I would repeat, bringing in black employees who have no previous relation with these jobs, no previous attempt to hold them.
We are simply asserting the rights of individuals who had they been white would have had this seniority, would have been able to compete among other things for protection from lay-off.
We do not think that a per se rule which says although these blacks may have been discriminated against in the past, they cannot have their remedy, if any whites expectations would be diminished.
We do not think that such a rule can be justified as a general matter.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Bowman’s operations do not present the problem either, do they where someone may have come in one capacity and gradually moved up to more and more responsible positions where you might have some question of job qualification for what that person is shooting for.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: This is a simple case involving in regard to this issue, one job.

There is no question of somebody being laid off who is less qualified than someone else, that would suggest different questions which I submit should be reserved for cases presenting a factual record.
I would like to address the Title VII issue primarily and the Section 1981 issue only briefly.
I would stress in regard to Title VII that this is basically a question of remedies and equity.
Do the vague and general terms of Section 703 (h) require a limitation on what this Court has found to be the sweeping provisions of Section 706 (G), the remedial Section.
This Court has given a broad to the power and duty of Federal Equity Courts in discrimination cases generally.

And in particular, in Albemarle Paper Company versus Moody has construed Title VII and its remedial section as giving the District Court’s sweeping and flexible powers to make the victims of discrimination whole.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Of course in Albemarle the statutes specifically and said including back pay, here it does not specifically deal with seniority.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist the section, remedial section of course is the same and it authorizes the award of any relief as maybe appropriate and we think that would apply to injunctive remedies as well as back pay.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well, would you think that seniority would follow as inexorably as back pay would in the typical case?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice Rehnquist I would think perhaps even more inexorably since a job gives to its holder not merely pay but also other benefits and seniority in a situation like this is a key to the job.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well then why did congress single out back pay and mention it in not single seniority?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice that provision, Section 706 (G) was modeled on Section 10 (c) of the NLRA which was concerned primarily with jobs.
I would have to assume that Congress had foremost in its mind that it was granting access to jobs and would have added the back pay provision simply to clarify that that too was an available remedy.
The Lower Courts in construing this provision have invariably from the beginning granted remedial seniority in the job seniority and department seniority cases.
There has never been any question that seniority rights can be modified where necessary to rectify discrimination.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Even at the expense of an innocent fellow employee?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, court after court has held that the expectations of white employees even though innocent of wrong doing maybe modified in order to grant full relief under the Act.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Was that before we had some things to say about the expectations of employees in the last two years, I would place it?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Those --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: School teachers cases for example?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, those decisions began to come down as soon as cases were decided on the merits in about 1968 and they have continued to the present.
I think there has been no question as to the viability of that doctrine in the case of Transfer Seniority Rights.
The only question here is whether there’s any distinction between transfer seniority and retroactive hiring seniority and we submit that there is not.

It would be anomalous to say that a black employee who was sent to a laborer job may now transfer to white jobs with his full seniority where as the back applicant who applied for the white job in the first place and was turned down can get no remedy.
That would be the effect of drawing a line between the well settled job seniority cases and these new retroactive seniority cases.

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Whom do you think is entitled to retroactive seniority, a class generally or is it someone who proves he was discriminated against and that he was qualified for a job and so on.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, in this case our class as defined by the District Court consists of individuals who applied and were rejected.
Only those individuals who were qualified or who proved that they are qualified would be reinstated and it is those individuals --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: There would be an individual determination in -- when you get to the matter of remedy.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: In this case I have stated the class and in any case it would be a matter for evidentiary determination by the District Courts in light of the applicable principles of equity and the make whole purpose of Title VII.
I would not think that there could be a general formulation of who would or would not be entitled to consideration in any case for retroactive seniority.
But in this case, the individuals for home relief is sought are clearly identified.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Alright, clearly identified but on what grounds would they be -- assume you prevailed would they -- all of those automatically receive the super seniority or would there still be proceedings in the individuals?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice the retroactive seniority I assume would only apply to individuals who are reinstated who actually work and that would depend on determinations as to their qualifications, etcetera.
Nobody would receive retroactive seniority who is not otherwise entitled to a job.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: But isn’t that pretty much the limits of your class, what you just described?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: As defined by the District Court, yes.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: So that all members of the class then would receive retroactive seniority.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: No, Mr. Justice Rehnquist.
This retroactive seniority would only accrue upon reinstatement.
The District Court did not order anyone reinstated.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: What do you mean reinstatement?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Hiring upon reapplication.
The District—

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Hiring in the first instance?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Well, post decree.
The District Court invited, ordered Bowman to invite reapplications.
Many individuals reapplied, only a few were hired.

The retroactive seniority claim is for those who were hired plus those whose rights we are no litigating in the District Court on remand who may be adjudged, entitled to reinstatement by the District Court.
Retroactive seniority is meaningless for those individuals who do not any longer have any interest in working at Bowman or who are not qualified.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But they still collect that some kind of damages.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: They would have a right to back pay if they had worked at Bowman without their retroactive seniority and we have several such individuals.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Baller, can you over --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Baller can you over, excuse me.

I am just speaking through memory now but a while back did we not have a similar kind of issue with respect to seniority under the Soldiers and Sailors Civil Relief Act when boys were coming back from service and they wanted in at the same time and at the same place as though they had worked continuously during their period of military service.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun --

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: I find those cases not cited by either side here and I wonder if they are completely impertinent.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: I am afraid Mr. Justice Blackmun that we simply overlooked those cases if they are pertinent.

We did note World War II cases in which returning veterans and individuals who were not employed at the time they were in the Army -- were allowed to secure retroactive seniority rights pursuant to a Collective Bargaining Agreement.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Well I have in mind specifically and I would be interested for one in post argument comments from both sides on Tilton against Missouri Pacific in 376 U.S. as to whether it has any bearing on the case.
I remember it very vividly because this Court reversed me and probably properly so.[laughing]

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Thank you Mr. Justice.
I would like to turn just briefly to the Section 1981 issue.
Our position is that whatever result the Court reaches under its analysis of Section 703 (H) and Title VII, the petitioners are entitled to retroactive seniority under Section 1981.
As this Court held in Johnson versus Railway Express Agency, Section 1981 remedies are independent and distinct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Excuse me Mr. Baller, may I just --getting back to the other issue.
Do we not have some of the issues we did not reach in the fullness and did not decide on these.
Do we have some of those working in the background here?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice Brennan I do not believe those are presented in the case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Well, I gather you that you regard this as simply a rightful place kinda case and not a preference case.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And nevertheless tend to think we should have -- maybe some overtones in the field.
Preference involved in this.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: There is no preference sought here Mr. Justice Brennan.
We seek for these black employees to be in the position which the record makes clear they would be in had they been white or had—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: -- Or these I gather are employees who in fact applied—

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: And were refused employment.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: Maybe a year or two ago and now they are getting -- they are being employed and they want to be employed where they would have been, had they been employed when they first applied.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So you do not have here, the maintenance of any racial structure or the like.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice, at the same time we do not think that based on the narrow record presented here, the Court can or should decide that only in the instance of a written application could an employee not be in a job which he otherwise would have been in.
They may well -- —

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What do we have here don’t we have (voice overlapped)

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is what we have in this case.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Only those who in fact applied.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And were refused employment.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And if we stick to that narrow question we do not reach any of these other suits.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct but I would stress that the Lower Courts frequently find discrimination in hiring in regard to people who did not apply, who were deterred from applying by a word of mouth recruitment system or by a reputation well known in a community that an employer would not hire blacks and so on.
Those claims while not present in this case should not be foreclosed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: The reinstatement with the retroactive seniority does could mean and would mean displacement of people with lesser seniority.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: It would not mean direct bumping out of jobs, people presently hold.
It would mean that—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You mean in this case?
Or in the case generally?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Well, in this case certainly we have not asked for that and I think generally the Courts have been reluctant to grant --

turn.speaker: byron_r_white
turn.label: Justice Byron R. White
turn.text: Well, but suppose the employers says, “Well, I just do not need that many people.
I have 50 people now and you say I must reinstate with super seniority 50 others.”
Would not the employer be entitled to release the people with lesser seniority.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice White, let me draw a distinction between cases in which a discriminatee is placed in a job held by a white employee who is immediately displaced and other situations --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Or any other employee—

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Or any other employee.

And situations such as this case and typical seniority cases being litigated in the Courts where what the discriminatees seek is a seniority right which they can exercise pursuant to the collective bargaining agreement.
Usually that means when jobs become vacant or are posted for bidding.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, anyway Mr. Baller, as I understand you what -- the fact situation we have here is this, there is a work force, that work force has been added to by employing these people who are previously been refused employment, is that not?
They have in fact been employed.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Several of them have, yes your Honor.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They are in fact been employed and their compliant is they have not been given their rightful place on the seniority roster.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is—

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: They ought to have the place that they would have had, had they been employed a year ago or two years ago.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: So we have not reached any of the questions that involve lay offs or other circumstances.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Those questions are not presented by the facts of the case.

turn.speaker: william_j_brennan_jr
turn.label: Justice William J. Brennan, Jr.
turn.text: But can you escape them?
Someday Bowman’s going to have lay people off, isn’t it?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice Brennan I believe the emphasis and much of the controversy in the case has been over the theory which justifies the rightful place result we seek and of course, the resolution of that theory will have implications for the future cases and we do not far from trying to hide them.
We would certainly urge that they be considered.

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Well these people certainly aren’t trying to --aren’t fighting over any abstract right of seniority in order to get a 25-year pin.
They want something tangible as a result, don’t they?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: That is correct.
Bidding Rights, security from lay off and fringe benefits.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Baller I guess I do not understand why you are so concerned about confessing that in the background there is the lay off possibly of other people.
What is wrong with that on your theory?
They may be innocent as the Chief Justice described them but they attained a spot that they should not have obtained, had the law been in effect, and hence I wonder why you are so sensitive about it?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Justice Blackmun I certainly wish to suggest that the issue is not lurking, it is there and under our theory, if blacks have retroactive seniority and a lay off comes and someone must be laid off it would be according to seniority.
There would be no preservation of expectations founded on past discrimination for whites.
Certainly we do not mean to suggest that we would not advance that position.
It does however raise different issues.
I would like to reserve the remainder of my time if I may.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Very well, Mr. Gottesman.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice may it please the Court.
The Union agrees with the relief which the petitioners seek in this case though not in its entirety with the analysis by which they get there.
I would like to begin by redefining as it were precisely who we are talking about here, precisely what they seek, because I think that is important to the analysis.
We are talking about a group of people who did apply for employment and whom the District Court found would have been hired but for the fact that they were black.
And the relief which is sought is sought only for those people who but for discrimination would have been hired at an earlier date.

Now, what the District Court said to this company was, “You shall now as vacancies arise, no bumping, but as vacancies arise, you shall now offer the next available vacancies to these group of people.”
But the District Court said, “When they finally get a job, their seniority date will only be from the date that you finally give them the job.”
And what they say is, “But for discrimination you would have hired us eight months ago or a year ago.”
And but for discrimination there for --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: How many of them have been hired?

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: The number is very small.
I do not have it.
We are talking about—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: What is the size of the group?

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Five, six, seven, something in that —

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Who have been hired?
What is the total group involved.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Mr. Baller who is involved at the trial level knows better.

Its at least several dozen but not all of those will be eligible for the relief because not all of them will prove to have been qualified at the time that they applied and thus it can not be said of all them.
That they would have have been hired but for the discrimination.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well at least the half dozen who have been found qualified and have been hired.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And as per them they have been getting their seniority from the date they were hired.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: That is right.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And they want it back to the date they first applied were discriminatorily refused to apply.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Well they wanted back to the date they would have have been hired.
It might be a few days or weeks after the first applied.
But they want in effect to be restored to the position that they would occupy had they never been discriminated against.
And that relief it seems to us and I will get into a statutory analysis in a moment.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, with the same approach Mr. Gottesman, or what’s your approach mean, that the District Court could have ordered them to work right away even though it meant bumping.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: There has been a lot of discussion in the Lower Courts.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well there maybe, but what’s your position?

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Our position is no, that in remedying discrimination generally under Title VII.

The Courts have adopted what is called The Rightful Place Approach which includes not only giving people the right seniority but, rather than bumping people saying, “You shall begin to exercise this seniority, the first the time a vacancy is created.”
Now, there is nothing in the statute that literally provides that.
But from 1967 when the decisions first came down until date, the Lower Courts have unanimously endorsed in the belief that more surely have been what Congress intended.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: And that is your position?

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Yes, it is.
Now as Mr. Baller said, in this case it makes no difference because vacancies arise every day and another case it make it a difference.
But whatever one decided about that, one thing is unmistakably clear that once an employee does get to work, he uses his full seniority under this theory for all purposes in the future.
There is no question that if a lay off comes, he will keep the job and the white who was hired earlier but after the date the black should have been hired will be laid off first.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: MR. Gottesman, is it clear to you that Congress never intended a remedy which would require bumping?

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: I can only say that so far as I know the legislative history is silent.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, why do you suggest that if the history did not -- statute did not require that in the way of a remedy, nevertheless the statute requires rightful place seniority.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Well if I may I can argue why we think the statute requires rightful place.
And I think it may become clear from that why it does not inevitably follow that it requires bumping.
At least immediate bumping because of course to give the people of the seniority means that there will inevitable bumping at the time of lay offs and other opportunity.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But you have got to approach this on the theory that the original reinstatement as a result of a claim followed by reinstatement with retroactive seniority may result either a, in the immediate bumping of X-number of people or at sometime in the future.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: That is correct.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: And then at some point will you suggest whether it did not occur to Congress that this might create some rights for a remedy on the part of the innocent “purchaser.”

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Well, let me address that because I think that is critical to the analysis here and it is obviously the source of some concern of Court.
It is true that the whites who were hired during this intervening period are innocent.
They have done no wrong, they have committed no violation of law.
And it is true that they will suffer a competitive disadvantage if this people are invested with their seniority.
But it does not follow as Mr. Justice Blackmun said that their having anything taken away form them, that should be a source of concern because they too are being in their rightful place.
When the black employee is advanced ahead of them on the seniority roster the white is simply being restored to the position he would have been in from the start.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Do you think that employee recognizes that he is being put in his rightful place.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Absolutely not, I can tell you from experience that he does not.
But we deal with Congress’ intentions not the employees.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But what in the legislative history suggests that Congress was not concerned at all about whether some employees were going to be displaced either from their seniority or from their actual employment.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Well, Congress was concerned about that in a wide variety of context other than the narrow one we are dealing with and if I can get into the statutory analysis, I think I can explain both the nature of that concern and its limits and why it does not extend to this case because there is no question that Congress was concerned about this.

Let me start by saying this, I think there is no question that the first sentence of Section 706(g) generally encompassed a Congressional intention to make people whole for the effects of discrimination visited against them to make whole those who suffer the discrimination.
And what in essence the Court below said is that there is carved out of this make whole remedy.
A category of relief which you cannot give even though it would make whole to with the retroactive seniority.
And so the focus our question has to be is that indeed, why Section 703(h) is in the statute.
Was it put there to put a limit on what would otherwise be legitimate make whole relief.
And I suggest that the answer that cannot come by looking first at Section 703(H).
The answer to that question has to come by looking at the history of the legislative debate.

Because when Congress, when this bill was first introduced and it was a bipartisan bill, Section 706(g) at that time not only had the first sentence to make whole provision, it also had a last sentence.
And the last sentence was what we have characterized as the anti-preference section.
It said, “You shall not give relief to people who were not the victims of discrimination.”
So that on the one hand you shall make whole those who are victims of discrimination, on the other you shall not give preference to those who were not victims of discrimination.
Now though -- the statutory language was very clear or the language of the bill was very clear.
That did not prevent its declaimers from going all over the countryside suggesting that that indeed was not what Title VII was going to mean.
And there was voice both on the floor of Congress and throughout the land because the period of time we are talking about was during the presidential primary of 1964.
The impending Title VII was an issue of great debate during that primary and at least one candidate made the defeat of that bill, one of his major issues.
And so we have the anomaly of Unions appearing before Congress saying “enact the statute.”
Well Congressmen were being inundated by letters from presumably white workers saying, “Do not pass that statute.
That statute is going to give all kinds preferences to people.”
Because indeed the detractors were saying this statute will give preferences.

And we were in the midst of a three month filibuster over this bill and the floor managers of the bill, Senators Clark and Case introduced literally an avalanche of written legislative history designed to reassure all of these concerns.
The theme of that repeatedly was this bill though it is designed to end discrimination and make whole its victims, is not intended to give any preferences to anybody on a count of race.

It is not designed to -- in one fell swoop cure an entire national history of discrimination all its designed to do is to make sure that from this day forward, employers and Union shall not discriminate.
And that the victims of that discrimination which occurs from this day forward will be made whole.
There will be no qoutas, there will not be no special seniority rights as they called it.
We are just going to stop discrimination as of this date and give remedies to those who suffer any continued discrimination.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is there not something mutually exclusive about those promises?

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Well, yes I think they are indeed, our brief suggests that they are mutually exclusive that they define a rather clear line between that which may be done and that which may not.
And as we see that line the line is, that you may give to the victim of discrimination.
That relief which will make him whole, that will restore him to the position that—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: This area at least Congress expressly rejected what (Inaudible) involved in a way of preferential --

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Well it seems clear to us and one of the place where we disagree with the petitioners is that they are unwilling to acknowledge that this statute clearly precludes preferences.
And by their unwillingness to acknowledge that they make the legal argument hazier than we think it ought to be.

We think it is very clear that once you recognize that that was the whole purpose of this additional provisions being tucked in to the of the back of the statute then you can see that that is not the purpose of Section 706(g) in its first sentence.
What 703(h) does and its part of a mosaic was that after the sponsors had literally grown hoarse resisting claims that this statute was a preference statute.
They were still confronted with the filibuster and they were still confronted with people screaming that indeed it did create preferences.
And so there was a whole revision of the bill, the so called “Dirksen-Mansfield Compromise Bill” which reincorporated the central provisions of the statute intact.
The provisions that define discrimination and the remedy provision.
But added a whole series of provisos that which 703(h) was one and 703(j), this sections that literally talks about no preferences being another.
And it is those sections whose meaning is really the critical issue before the court.
But --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: But can you find anything in this several sections particularly 706(g) which draws the distinction between pre-act discrimination and post-act.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: No, on that we are dependent upon the statements of Senator Clark and Case in the Department of Justice, all of which are clearly writ in the Legislative History.
And they made it clear in essence that that line was drawn because they said the Act only forbids discrimination from this date forward.
So that it may be true for example that last week an employer refused to hire someone.

But that person is not the victim of discrimination within the meaning of the statute and therefore he is no t entitled to a make whole remedy because he was discriminated against before this law was passed.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: You do not think, you mean last week before the law --

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: I am sorry, last week before the law was passed.
I am sorry, forgive me.

But they were saying as of July 2, 1965, anyone who from that date forward is discriminated against, is the victim of discrimination within the meaning of the statute, and he therefore shall get a remedy.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) for post act violations?

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: He is to be made whole, he has to be given the position that he would have have occupied but for discrimination.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well he is going to be in this case as vacancies occur he is to be preferred.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: He will, in that sense, yes, but that is not what we mean by preference.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Well, I am just saying that all right, that that he is just being preferred.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Yes, sure.
In one sense of preferred, he is preferred.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: We always prefer, in the sense of somebody else does not get the job.
And the reason is that because he has been discriminated against.

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: That is right.

Now, but we think 703(h) means is that it is conformation as is 703(j) and is so much of the written legislative history, that there is not to be a more general kind of preference, there is not to be a judgment made for example, this employer never hired blacks until 1972.
Therefore we ought to say that 'x' % of blacks hired in the future will be given an arranged of seniority dates in order to slot them into some non-discriminatory and seemingly reasonable [Inaudible]

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: That is what they act affirmatively prohibits you, you said it, is it not?

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: You say in fact petitioners are entitled to what they ask for here but they are not entitled to anything broader than that?

turn.speaker: michael_h_gottesman
turn.label: Mr. Michael H. Gottesman
turn.text: Well and they do not seek anything broader in this case but there are other cases where broader relief is sought.
We discussed some in our brief.
Watkins is the clearest one, but there are a range, we are not suggesting that we have the answer all at one time for the entire range of facts.

What for example of the employee who did not apply for a job in 1970 because he knew this company did not hire blacks but who comes forward in 1972 and says, “I should get two years of seniority would have been feudal to apply.”
That involves some of the fact type questions this Court dealt with in Blue Chips Stamps and in an entirely different context.
We are not suggesting the answer to that, I think that is something that has to be litigated in the future but from that litigation will emerge an answer.
That person either is or is not the victim of discrimination.
The ultimate determination is that he is a victim of discrimination then he will be entitled to make whole.
If the answer is that he is not because unless you apply for a job, you are not a victim then he will not be entitled to any seniority.

And so the line we see is a very clear one but it is important to see both sides of the line because if you only try to look at one as petitioners do, you slide into the problem that everybody says “But where does this line stop.”
And to us the line is very clear, the two sides of it at least in this case are clear and this case falls on the make whole side.
Petitioners seek nothing but that which they would have had but for discrimination.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Mr. Pate.

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice, may it please the court.
We are not seeking to sustain Court of Appeal's interpretation of Section 703(h).
We agree with the other parties that the interpretation is not correct.
That is our view.
We do not agree with everything that the other parties are saying en route to that conclusion.
We think that it is clear form the legislative history and from that terms and words of the statute itself that this Section was intended to have a definite effect.
It was intended to place a limitation both on the substantive provisions of Title VII and on the remedies that are available under it.
Now there has been discussion of the distinction between pre-act discrimination and post-act discrimination.
That distinction, I would I say is a starting point, I would consider valid.
However, I would go farther than that.

I think that Congress was drawing a distinction here between the discrimination which is the subject of the case that is specifically before the Court indicates and for which it is framing a remedy, as compared with general discrimination in the past which is it not seeking to remedy in the case.

For example, I think that Congress foresaw the concept which has developed under this statute, I might say different from anything under the National Labor Relations Act to which it has been compared under which practices which are racially neutral in themselves are held to be violative of the Act because of their continuation of the effects of past discrimination including pre-act discrimination.

Now, Congress apparently saw that and the legislative history demonstrates that it was consigned that the statute would taken its sweep, seniority rights under numerous seniority systems over the country either under Union Contracts or under company policy.
Well, the system itself had been affected by race discrimination in the past and even those that might be affected by racial discrimination in the future.
So, we think that is the important distinction in Section 703(h).
Now, concededly here, the discrimination that we are talking about occurred after Title VII.
Consequently, we are not talking about just a system that continuously affect the past discrimination.

Now its our view that in the case of this kind that the Court has the same kind of discretion that the National Labor Relations Board would have and has had for a number of years in framing remedies for discrimination cases under that statute.
It has been noted that the remedial provisions of this act were to some extent modeled after the National Labor Relations Act.

It is always been considered under that statute, that the restoration of seniority for discharged employee is a part of his reinstatement, was an available remedy, usually they ought to reach without prejudice to seniority all other rights and privileges previously enjoy it or some similar wording and a similar remedy has frequently been framed for employees who had discriminatorily rejected for employment.
Now we think that those remedies were intended to be available at the discretion of the Court that was framing the remedy under Title VII, just as they were under the National Labor Relations Act.
Now, we think though that the discretion of the court still has an important role.

Now I am aware of course of the decision of this Court in the Albemarle case, I am aware of the holdings that the discretion calls for judgment and not just inclination and that it must be exercised consistently with purposes of the statute.
We submit that there was support in this record for the action which the District Court took and that he did act properly within his discretion.
Now on appeal, the Court of Appeals, although making this interpretation of Section 703(h) concluded with the holding that the District Court did not abuse its discretion in withholding this remedy.
Now, I want to refer particularly to the factual situation that was before the Court, there had been exhaustive discovery before this case was tried.
These people were identified clearly and full information had been provided to the other parties, about all of them.
There were some 200 of these applicants in this category.

They got all the documents relating to them and had a full information about the company’s action on each case including the reasons advanced by the company for the disqualification of different ones under the criteria that the company was applying.

They had full opportunity to interview these people, there was nothing to keep them from it and I might say that answers to subject when interrogators have indicated that they did in fact interview them though I assume they did not interview all of them.
Two of them in addition to the class representative himself testified.
Also witnesses for the company testified about the way in which different individuals were disqualified that were in this group.

Now, the District Court on the basis of this record made the statement as part of the basis for his denial of his relief that there was no evidence in the record on which he could base the multiple conclusions necessary for an award of retroactive seniority.

Also, I think the fact that it makes very little difference in this particular case, under the facts that seniority has such a small effect among the road drivers in view of the high rate of turn over and also in view of the fact that there is very little by way of job benefits that really depends on seniority.
The main thing --

turn.speaker: william_h_rehnquist
turn.label: Justice William H. Rehnquist
turn.text: Could you not argue precisely the opposite of that effect that there will not be much displacement or much defeat of expectations of people who are already there, so why not go ahead and give it.

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: I think you could make that argument, yes, I think that you could, it would not make much difference either way and perhaps the argument could be made either way but I think it was a proper consideration for the District Court although he did not -- the Court did not say that it was relying on that consideration in any event on this point.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Did the Court of Appeals address itself to this?

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: The Court of Appeals did not addressed itself to this other than to make the general holding that I am talking about that—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Inaudible) let's assume the Court of Appeals was wrong or they (Inaudible)

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: Well, lets, I could certainly understand—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: (Or do you want to say that even it was wrong, the District Court was right.

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: The District Court was right and the holding of the Court of Appeals was that the District Court did not abuse its discretion. So that gives further support to the --

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Mr. Pate I do not fully understand.
Right in what respect, these people in any event were not qualified?

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: I am not saying that the people were not qualified but that there was a proper basis in the record for the District Court’s with holding in its discretion of this remedy.
The Court of Appeals concluded that the District Court did not abuse its discretion in withholding the remedy.

Consequently, I say that their interpretation of 703(h) may not have been the same, I may have been incorrect but nevertheless they reached the right conclusion, sustained the District Court and therefore the factors which affected the District Courts discretion would be material now, I think.
I might say also that I think that the discretion under Rule 23 CD to control the issues to be handled by a class action was an important factor here.

There had been no certification of a class action until the conclusion of the evidence indicates and it was at that point that this class action was approved and certified in its final findings, conclusions and decree by the District Court.
He referred to another decision.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Excuse me, where are you referring?

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: I referred to -- he referred to another decision as given his reasons more fully in which he had stated that he wanted to avoid being inundated by this mass of individual claims.
So I would submit that he did have the discretion to control the class action by limiting the issues that he was handling on that basis.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How specifically is Bowman Transportation Company injured if—

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: I beg your pardon, I said yes.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: How is Bowman injured?

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: By seniority.
By the grant of this remedy?

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: Either way.

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: It is not injured either way and the company apart from the general interest of all of us and the importance of the question has no specific tangible interest ended in this case as to whether seniority is granted to this group or not, that is correct.
I want to say I have --

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Is their lurking here the possibility of a potential injury in the sense that it had displaced employee, displaced by a virtue of the retroactive seniority might bring a suit against Bowman.
Not in the setting of this case but in the overall picture.

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: That maybe lurking in the background Mr. Chief Justice, I had never thought of it as a possibility.
You are thinking of a displaced white employee bringing suit because he is displaced as a result of a grant of retroactive seniority.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: When you come to the day of a lay off or when you come to the day when two men are competing for a job and one gets it because he has been granted retroactive seniority.

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: Let us go back to the National Labor Relations Act where that kind of situation has repeated it self many times and it has never been urged that the employee displaced by the employers compliance where the remedial order would himself have a claim because it is a sort of reversed discrimination under terms of that statute.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Well of course, supposed we have all got to bear in mind that a great many new causes of action that we did not think about years ago are now suddenly emerging.

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: I think that is correct, your Honor.

turn.speaker: thurgood_marshall
turn.label: Justice Thurgood Marshall
turn.text: But as of now you are not into it?

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: As of now the company would not be injured by it.
Now, we have contended and do contend that this part of the case is moot in any event.
Because of the class representative is out of the class now.
He has no further stake in the outcome of this case since he lost his discharge case which followed his employment after he had originally been denied for employment for a period of time.

turn.speaker: unknown_speaker
turn.label: Unknown Speaker
turn.text: Which one was this, Mr. Pate?

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: This is a Lee the intervenor, he attacked his refusal to hire him, the failure to hire him for a period of several months and his subsequent discharge as being racially discriminatory.
He was sustained on the refusal to hierarchies but he was unsuccessful on the discharge case and he was unsuccessful on appeal in the discharge case.

Consequently the only representative of the class to which this part of the case relates is the inovina who wrote a separate inovina’s complaint and he now has no stake whatsoever in the outcome of this question and consequently we say under the test enunciated by this Court in Sosna versus Utah and related cases since this is not a question capable of repetition, while evading review.
That it dose not come within that narrow exception which this Court talked about for certain class actions where that kind of question is presented.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: But these class members certainly have a substantial financial stake in the outcome of the litigation, do they not Mr. Pate?

turn.speaker: william_m_pate
turn.label: Mr. William M. Pate
turn.text: The class members have a financial stake in the outcome of the litigation.
They have a stake in the seniority question as well.
But looking to the named parties for the determination of this question of mootness or question of case or controversy under Article 3, there is no named party in the case that has any stake in.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you, you have about four minutes left Mr. Baller.

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Mr. Chief Justice and may it please the Court.

Just a couple of brief points in rebuttal as to mootness, our position is that because the existence of class members where their lives stake in the controversy and a certified class action, the case does fit within the Sosna Rule and it is viable.
Moreover, Johnny Lee had a life claim at the time the case was certified.

With respect to discretion I submit that the Court reviews what the District Court and the Court of Appeals actually held, it will see quite clearly that this was not an exercise of discretion nor was it affirmed as such by the Court of Appeals rather they were erroneous rules of law.

With respect to the effect of this on, presumably innocent white employees, I would simply note that as the court has frequently held, seniority being contractual is subject to modification to conform with law.
And focusing on the innocence of affected employees would create the kind of subjective standard which this Court has abjured in Griggs and other employment discrimination cases.

Finally with regard to the reliance by Mr. Gottesman on the Clark Case materials to create a distinction between pre-act and post-act discrimination which he conceives is reflected nowhere in the statute itself, I would simply state to the Court our position that the Lower Courts have made it clear that Clark Case materials cannot be read literally to convey the Congressional intention on their face, they are far broader than both the terms of the statute and broader than any construction, the Court’s have been willing to give in stating that no pre-1965 seniority rights would ever be affected by any Title VII action.
That simply has not been an acceptable interpretation in the Courts.

Finally, I would just call to the Court's attention that all we seek is the same as this Court has accorded to all claims of employment discrimination brought under Title VII from Griggs through Albemarle Paper that is a construction which assures that victims of discrimination will have a chance to prove in court that they were wrong and upon proof of discrimination that they are entitled to ask complete relief as is possible in the circumstances.
We fee that this petitioners deserve no less.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: harry_a_blackmun
turn.label: Justice Harry A. Blackmun
turn.text: Mr. Baller if you loose under Title VII could you still prevail under 1981?

turn.speaker: morris_j_baller
turn.label: Mr. Morris J. Baller
turn.text: Yes, Mr. Justice Blackmun.
Section 1981 is a separate remedy.

We feel that the interference with contractual rights in the nature of seniority benefits, is it violates the prohibition in Section 1981 on discrimination in making an enforcement of contracts and there should be a cause of action with a right retroactive seniority to restore those contractual benefits.

Congress specifically rejected amendments that would have made Title VII the exclusive remedy for employment discrimination and as this Court held in Alexander, it did not mean in enacting Title VII to repeal pre-existing remedies.
Thank you.

turn.speaker: warren_e_burger
turn.label: Chief Justice Warren E. Burger
turn.text: Thank you gentlemen.
The case is submitted.
